title: 108_s851
content: The "Child Custody Protection Act" may be cited as the short title. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter on the transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion. The "Child Custody Protection Act" introduces a new chapter in Title 18, United States Code, addressing the transportation of minors across state lines for abortions, in violation of parental involvement laws. Transporting a minor with the intent for them to obtain an abortion, thereby bypassing parental rights, is punishable by fine or imprisonment. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization, except in cases where the minor's life is endangered by a physical condition related to the pregnancy. Transporting a minor in violation of this law will not result in prosecution or lawsuits for the minor or her parents. The "Child Custody Protection Act" prohibits transporting a minor across state lines for an abortion without parental consent or judicial authorization. An affirmative defense is available if the defendant reasonably believed that the necessary consent or notification had been obtained. Parents can seek civil relief for violations of the act. A law requiring parental involvement in a minor's abortion decision includes notification or consent from a parent, legal custodian, or person in loco parentis. The text chunk defines the term 'minor' as an individual not older than the maximum age requiring parental notification or consent in a law regarding abortion decisions. It also includes the definition of 'State' to encompass various territories of the United States. Transportation of minors in circumvention of certain laws relating to abortion.
